awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Nanoscale Physics and Materials REU and RET at Penn State
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: 
Science, technology, and engineering careers are becoming increasingly dependent on a breadth of knowledge that spans multiple disciplines. This Research Experience for Undergraduates and Teachers at Penn State University addresses this need for multi-disciplinary breadth by engaging a highly diverse group of 10 students and two teachers in cross-disciplinary research in nanoscale physics and materials. Students and teachers will learn and apply cutting-edge scientific techniques and experience the challenges and rewards of working in a collaborative, interdisciplinary research environment. Undergraduate students will also participate in career development activities focused on fortifying the non-technical skills necessary for success in scientific research, including scientific communication and skills for building mentor-mentee relationships. Activities include scientific seminars, professional networking events, outreach activities, and participation in a national conference.  Teachers will gain materials science knowledge and transfer their experiences back to their students, influencing them and their community through the development of teaching resources with their peers and Penn State faculty. This research experience aims to inspire and prepare students of all ages to pursue careers in science and engineering, with specific goals to increase representation in science from underrepresented groups, including minorities and women. Most students from this program matriculate to graduate programs in science and engineering or begin careers in science disciplines.
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS: 
This Research Experience for Undergraduates and Teachers in nanoscale physics and materials emphasizes the investigation, creation and/or manipulation of novel nanostructures and low dimensional materials in order to understand and harness their electrical, optical, magnetic or quantum mechanical properties. Students will participate in 10 weeks of mentored research in projects ranging from the fundamental study of novel physics in topologically active thin films, nanoparticles, few-layered and 2D materials, to the design, testing and application of these materials in devices. Teachers participate in a similar 6-week research project coupled with education-themed scientific workshops. Through their research, students and teachers will have the opportunity to be trained on state-of-the-art materials synthesis and characterization equipment. Complementing their research, students also participate in career development activities aimed at preparing them for and exposing them to scientific research in nanoscale physics and materials.  The culmination of their research experiences will be to present their work at a cross-disciplinary undergraduate research symposium at Penn State and some will travel to present their findings at a national conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From 2019 to 2024, this NSF-REU Site: Nanoscale Physics and Materials REU and RET at Penn State supported or partially supported 36 students to participate in 10 weeks of individual materials research projects in experimental, theoretical, or computational research in condensed matter physics or novel nanoscale materials.  In line with NSF-REU goals, 63% of these REU students were from undergraduate institutions where research is limited, and 40% were from typically underrepresented minority groups. In 2019, 2022, and 2023 this award partially supported one REU student each year who otherwise was supported by another NSF grant. In 2019, and 2022 we ran fully in-person REU programs. In 2020 we hosted a fully remote REU, and in 2021 a hybrid REU program. In 2023, the REU-site grant was in a no-cost extension year, and the site partially support one student, who was still able to fully engage in an REU cohort and professional development program due to the engagement of other students as explained below. 

From 2019-2023 this REU site invited 52 students funded by other NSF sources, including Penn State’s Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (NSF-MRSEC and NSF-PREM) and three faculty NSF awards, who were participating in adjacent cutting edge individual research projects, to participate in the REU-site sponsored career-preparatory professional development activities. The REU impact was further broadened by inviting 29 Penn State Physics supported by the Penn State Physics Department and other faculty-funds to join the program and serve as 'hosts' to the visiting students. This diverse group of students was mentored by top researchers on independent research projects, attended weekly seminars, participated in professional development workshops related to scientific communication, engaged in public outreach, and participated in a summers-end symposium with researchers from across Penn State summer research programs. These activities provided them with experience in research and professional preparation for graduate school and future STEM careers. 

This site also supported 4 teachers in 2019 and 2022 (joined by 7 others funded by the Penn State MRSEC) to engage in a 6-week RET, where they engaged in their own research projects with faculty and their research labs and participated in workshops in nanotechnology and other scientific issues.  In 2020, the RET was suspended due to the pandemic, and in 2021 4 RET with 15 others (supported by MRSEC) participated instead in a MRSEC-hosted, novel 2-week 3-hour a day online virtual research exposure and professional development workshop series focused on materials research at Penn State and sustainability concepts teachers could incorporate into the classroom. 7/8 Teachers were recruited from PA, and the 8th teaches at a predominantly Native Indian school in Arizona, aligning our proposed impact locally and to underrepresented populations. Teachers gained material science knowledge which they transferred to classroom activities through their development of take-home resources in collaboration with their peers, Penn State faculty and their research groups. Teachers who returned for a second year added to the program by contributing content to the workshop activities, by sharing prior RET lesson plans with other teacher participants.

This REU Site emphasized the importance of both the interdisciplinary nature of materials research and scientific communication. 99% of students reported that they gained appreciation of how research in materials is interdisciplinary. Student and teachers were also trained in and practiced presentation skills. They all presented their research outcomes via oral and poster presentations at a multi-site end-of summer research symposium at Penn State each year. REU research resulted in 16 publications and 22 national or local conference presentations which were produced with undergraduate and teacher researchers who participated in this program, with 14 more publications by our broader community of host students. 80% of graduated NSF funded REU students from 2019-2023 began graduate or professional school in science and engineering another 10% started STEM careers.

This REU and RET site also provided a broader impact to the institutional and local communities. Locally, REU students participated in science outreach to the local community each year in a variety of ways, even throughout the Covid pandemic, from volunteering to present activities at science-themed summer camps at Discovery Space Center, to presenting science demos at Arts Fest Kids Day in July in State College. Starting in 2020, REU students hosted a panel for Upward Bound High School summer-camp students (from low-income school districts) all about life as a college student. RET fellows brought their research back to their students in the classroom in the form of tangible lesson plans, and ideas for incorporating new content into the classroom. Institutionally, student “hosts” and those funded by other NSF grants were able to cohort and gain professional experience, and skills, while graduate and postdoctoral mentors of REU students were impacted through their professional mentor training provided by the REU program and through mentoring practice helping to improve their own skill-set for future careers.
